Title: Kuru Otlar Üstüne (The Tender Grasses)
Director: Nuri Bilge Ceylan
Release Year: 2023
Genre: Drama
Language: Turkish
Running Time: 197 minutes
Cast: Deniz Celiloglu as Samet, Merve Dizdar as Nuray, Musab Ekici as Kenan, Ece Bagci, Erdem Senocak as Tolga, Yuskel Aksu as Veteriner Vahit, Onur Berk Arslanoglu as Bekir, Yildirim Gucuk as Milli Egitim Muduru, Cengiz Bozkurt as Nail, Serkan Aksoy as Sergeant, Saide Temizer as Assistant Principal Saime, Ferhat Akgun as Guidance Counselor Atakan, Eylem Canpolat as Halime, Seckin Aydin as Soldier Erdi, Turan Selcuk Yerlikaya as Petty Officer, Abti Karatas as Ranger, and Vahit Yildirim as Ranger with the Sleigh.
Screenplay: Ebru Ceylan, Nuri Bilge Ceylan, and Akin Aksu
Producer: Nuri Bilge Ceylan
Editor: Nuri Bilge Ceylan
Music: Ahmet Karaman
Cinematography: Gokhan Tiryaki
Producers: Nuri Bilge Ceylan Film, Iklim Film, Why Not Productions, Folkebiofilm Stockholm AB, and WDR Fiction

Plot Summary:
Set in rural Turkey, a small-town school teacher named Samet compares himself to dry grass waiting for spring. He dreams of being transferred back to the city's school but is shattered when an anonymous love letter written by one of his students is discovered. The accusations that follow lead him into a spiral of despair. His relationships with colleagues worsen, and he finds solace only in encounters with a new female colleague who helps him navigate through this difficult period.

Awards & Festivals:
* Cannes Film Festival - Official Selection, In Competition (2023)
* European Film Awards - Nominated for Best European Film, Best Director, Best Actress, and Best Screenwriter (2023)

Quotes:
"The film is a self-reflective and cautionary tale about the consequences of sexual misconduct and the importance of empathy and understanding." - Variety

"An introspective and thoughtful exploration of human nature and its capacity for both good and evil." - IndieWire

Reviews:
"With masterfully composed frames and subtle performances, 'The Tender Grasses' offers a poignant reflection on the complexities of desire, power dynamics, and redemption." - Hollywood Reporter

"A beautifully crafted and deeply moving drama that challenges us to confront our own biases and prejudices." - RogerEbert.com

"Nuri Bilge Ceylan delivers another hauntingly beautiful and intellectually stimulating work of art." - CinemaSight
